text_en: 450 Clinical Descriptions and Diagnostic Requirements for ICD-11 Mental, Behavioural or Neurodevelopmental Disorders The remaining diagnoses reflect the impact of the substance use pattern, and are thus considered to be associated with one of the primary use pattern diagnoses. These diagnoses should therefore be assigned together with the relevant primary diagnosis. For example, 6C49.1/6C49.5 is harmful pattern of use of hallucinogens associated with hallucinogen-induced psychotic disorder, 6C43.2/6C43.70 is opioid dependence associated with opioid-induced mood disorder, and 6C4Z/6C40.3 is disorder due to substance use, unspecified, associated with alcohol intoxication (i.e. the pattern of use in this last case is unknown). Also listed in this section are categories related to hazardous substance use. These categories are not considered to be mental disorders, but may be used when the pattern of substance use appreciably increases the risk of harmful physical or mental health consequences, to the user or to others, to an extent that warrants attention and advice from health professionals, but no overt harm has yet occurred.
